text: 123456 Psychophysics = the study of how the mind interprets the physical properties of stimuli  (waves of light or sound, chemical compounds)  The formal term for the psychological study of sensation and perception is psychophysics. Two areas that are of interest are the absolute threshold for a stimulus and the just noticeable difference (or difference threshold). Right now we are being struck by x-rays, radio waves, ultraviolet and infrared light, and sound waves at very high and low frequencies…but we are blind and deaf to this. Our senses are not a simple recording of all the available information in the world. There are limitations to what we can see and hear. Other animals with differing needs detect a world that lies beyond our experience Our senses open just a crack, allowing us restricted awareness of this vast 7 sea of energy Absolute threshold = what stimulus intensity is needed for it to be detected at all 50% of the time, -For example, a hearing specialist would test your hearing by exposing each of your ears to varying sound levels. For each tone of the sound level, the test would look for where you are able to detect the tone half the time. This is your absolute threshold. Noticeable difference = how much a stimulus must change in order for that change to be recognized at least 50% of the time. Weber’s law – the psychological principle that states that for each of our five senses, the amount of change in the stimulus that is necessary to produce a jnd (just noticeable difference) depends on the intensity at which the stimulus is first present (tsp salt in very salty soup vs. unsalted soup) 78910 For vision to occur, our eyes must be able to convert the electromagnetic waves of the  visible spectrum of light into action potentials that our brains can process.  The stimulus for our vision is light energy Cornea = clear, slightly bulging outer surface of the eye that both protects the eye and  begins the focusing process Iris = colored part of the eye, composed of rings of muscles that control the size of the  pupil Pupil = opening in the iris where light can enter the eye Sclera = white part of the eye, supporting structure, helping to accommodate the lens,  does not play a direct role in vision Lens = part of the eye that lies behind the pupil and focuses light rays on retina Retina = the structure at the back of the eye that contains cells that convert light into  neural signals 11 The retina has 2 types of specialized cells that convert light waves into neural  impulses….plus, several other supporting cells (amacrine, bipolar, horizontal and  ganglion cells). Light energy changes triggers chemical changes in the rods and cones.  This sets off a chain reaction that initiates a neural impulse, that is then sent to the  brain via the optical nerve Rods = the light sensitive cells of the retina that pick up any type of light energy and  convert it to neural signals (B & W)  Cones = the cells of the retina that are sensitive to specific colors of light and send  information to the brain concerning the colors we are seeing Fovea = point directly behind retina where cones are concentrated  Neural impulses leave retina and travel to the brain via the optical nerve = the structure that  conveys visual information away from the retina to the brain. *There are no rods or cones in  the area where the optic nerve exits the retina = blindspot, point in our visual field that we  cannot see 11 Neural signals travel from retina to brain via optic nerve Right eye sent to left hemisphere and left eye to right Optic chiasm –point in the brain where the optic nerve from R eye crosses optic nerve  from L eye Signals sent first to thalamus (remember the thalamus is the part of the forebrain that  functions as the sensory relay station), then is sent on the to visual cortex 121314 Just as we see light waves, we hear sound waves. There are qualities of each wave that determines the nature of what we hear. The frequency (Hz) is related to the pitch of the tone, and the amplitude (dB) is related to the loudness of what we hear. Human beings can hear between 20 and 20,000 hz. We loose range of pitches as we age (esp. higher pitches) Urban areas and noisy work environments = greater rates of hearing loss (60/60 rule for personal listening devices) The structures of the ear that allow us to have an auditory system are important for you to know, so make sure to review them: 1. Outer Ear – funnel and amplify sound toward eardrum - Pinna – ear lobes - auditory canal - tympanic membrane – ear drum – very thin membrane that vibrates as incoming sound waves strike it 15 2. Middle Ear – houses small bones that amplify the vibrations from the eardrum; middle ear connects to the inner ear at the point where the stirrup rests against the oval window, which is at the outer end of the cochlea – hammer – anvil – stirrup 3. Inner Ear – oval window – Cochlea = curled, fluid filled tube in the inner ear that contains the basilar membrane – basilar membrane – contains hair cells that convert sound waves to neural impulses – hair cells • Auditory nerve is attached to the end of the cochlea. • Auditory information from each ear reaches both hemispheres • Goes through thalamus then to auditory cortex  1516 Perception = organization and interpretation of sensory information Our brain does more than register information about the world. Perception is not just  opening a shutter and letting a picture print itself on the brain. We filter incoming  information and construct perceptions Our perception of the world is NOT a one‐to‐one reflection of the world. Our hearing is not  just recording sound, like a tape player. Our vision is not like a video camera we can play  back in our head. Our senses pick up signals from the world and send them to our brain.  Our brain puts the signals together and interprets them. These interpretations are fallible  and sensitive to our own physical limitations = we can only see a certain range of  wavelengths, whereas butterflies and mantis shrimp have a MUCH larger spectrum of  visible light. Image on our retina is 2‐D, but we perceive the world in 3‐D The sheer vast volume of sensory information we encounter constantly means that we do not perceive it all - and good thing! That would take a lot of our cognitive capacity. 1718 Top‐down perceptual processing ‐ occurs when we use previously gained  knowledge to help us interpret a stimulus; can also fill in parts of a stimulus that are  missing from actual sensation of it (blindspot) = Sometimes leads to mistaken perception…which can be a big problem in things  like eyewitness testimony Bottom‐up perceptual processing –perception that is not guided by prior  knowledge or experiences = uses the properties of the stimulus itself to build  perception If you are told that the red sauce in front of you is ketchup when it is actually tomato paste, you might experience the taste as being closer to ketchup. This demonstrates the importance of top-down processing, which tells us how expectations can sway or influence our perceptions. If, on the other hand, you were blindfolded and fed a spoonful of sauce, you’d probably build a more accurate perception of the flavors. In this case, you are rapidly analyzing the individual units of flavor from the “ground up” 19 and are not being influenced by experience or expectations. This is bottom-up processing. We use both continuously 1920 Perceptual Constancy = your perception of an object is not as dependent on perspective as sensation is (a person 3 feet away is a different actual size on your retina than a person 6 ft away, and yet our brains make the adjustment without our even realizing it) Sometimes we are fooled, often very easily, by the sensory stimuli in our surroundings These perceptual illusions can cause us to think that we are sensing something that does not exist. What is particularly curious about these phenomena is that the knowledge that we are not seeing (or hearing, etc.) our environment accurately does not cause us to start doing so. If you look at the Muller-Lyer illusion as an example, the knowledge that the vertical lines are the same length does not cause you to see them as equal. If you recall that top-down processing shows us how our expectations can influence our perceptions, it is easy to understand how our cultural surroundings can influence our perceptions. Once again, the Muller-Lyer illusion is an example to consider. Refer to your textbook’s discussion of how living in “carpentered environments” changes our perception of this distortion 21 of vision. 21222324252627 Subliminal Perception: when the intensity of a stimulus is below the participant’s absolute  threshold and the participant is not consciously aware of the stimulus • Famous claim by Vicary that using subliminal messages in a movie theater caused  popcorn sales to increase (= subliminal persuasion; note this was not a methodologically  sound study) • There is evidence that we can and sometimes do process subliminal sensations below  the level of our awareness…but this is not the same as being persuaded by them • Many studies have failed to yield convincing evidence for the effectiveness of persuasive subliminal messages • Some studies suggest that when certain criteria are met, subliminal persuasion  can occur, but is often subtle and fleeting. Extrasensory Perception (ESP): the purported ability to acquire information about the  world without using the known senses (sight, hearing, smell, taste, touch, body senses)  • Not supported by evidence  Researchers have also looked at a hypothetical phenomenon called extrasensory perception, or ESP. This is presented here as hypothetical because the vast majority of scientific data have failed, using various techniques, to validate the existence of such amazing abilities. Do you 28 believe they exist? Remember that psychology values critical thinking, which includes a willingness to be skeptical about amazing claims and a search for alternate explanations of those claims. 28
